ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: Miscellaneous comments on study, interview, methodology relevant to this form data
I would find it perfectly acceptable having to take MS for several years.
I take MS now and then, whenever I feel I need to.
It is definitely worth taking despite its side effects.
Taking MS exactly as prescribed fits in very easily with my daily routine.
Finding relief from personal stress is more important than taking MS in keeping me well.
I consider that MS is at present necessary for my personal well-being.
I worry about possible side-effects from my MS tablets, even when I'm feeling well.
Most people I know would probably be in favor of my taking MS.
I sometimes try to forget I have been ill by taking a break from MS tablets.
I rely on my tablets and if they were stopped I would be concerned.
People often have to remind me to take my MS tablets.
MS is just as acceptable to me when I consider the need for repeated blood tests and checkups.
I often think that since MS is an artificial way to keep stable I should be able to do without it.
It is very easy to remember to take MS at the right time.
I often doubt that my condition is sufficiently serious to justify the long-term use of MS.
I have an adequate factual knowledge of MS and its effects.
Being weak for several months would make me consider coming off MS.
If my daily routine changes for any reason I have difficulty in remembering to take my tablets.
I am convinced of the beneficial effects of MS from my own personal experience of taking it.

Do you think you would benefit from getting information on the impact of substance use on managing your bipolar disorder? (Note: Rater should let Interventionist know if pt assigned to MET only due to answering "yes" this item)
